p: Other than plants and fungi, marine cyanobacteria have been a promising source of secondary metabolites with potential medicinal use. As an example, chlorophyll derivatives 13 2-hydroxy-pheopytin-a and the novel 13 2-hydroxy-pheofarnesin-a were recently isolated from Cyanobium sp. LEGE 07,175 -and Nodosilinea sp. LEGE 06001, respectively. The zebrafish Nile red fat metabolism assay confirmed a neutral lipid-reducing activity of both compounds after 48 h of exposure, with no toxic effects. In order to explain the biological mechanism behind this activity profile, 13 2-hydroxy-pheopytin-a was found to increase PPARÎ³ mRNA expression. In light of these data, the presence of this compound in several foods, such as spinach, cabbage, Spirulina and Chlorella, makes it an important nutraceutical agent [ 73].
